description: Excel 2016 Advanced explores ways to enhance Excel workbooks with topics in analyzing data, collaborating and workbook security, and adding graphical elements. This series covers important Excel functionality such as format as table, conditional formatting, shared workbooks and tracked changes, and data validation. While Excel 2016 Advanced is a continuation from the Excel 2016 Essentials series, it can be viewed as a standalone show for users looking to take their Excel skills to the next level.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how to analyze data using sort and filter functions in Excel 2016. Sorting changes the order of all your data either by date, price, or alphabetically. Filter shows data based on your criteria. They also explore more advanced techniques with custom sorts and custom filters.
episodes.title: Sort and Filter

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne will explore conditional formatting which allows you to automatically apply formats to a cell or range of cells based on cell values. They demonstrate the different types of rules and how to customize formatting.
episodes.title: Conditional Formatting

sorts of different ways of this rules.

so you can go into that new rule or

357

And then just play around to
your heart's content until it

00:18:44.940 --> 00:18:46.610

359
00:18:46.610 --> 00:18:49.990
So you can combine conditional
formatting with sorts and

360

361

362

>> So you can combine and

>> All right, little Joshua tree.

365

>> [LAUGH]
>> Good one!

>> See, I'm there.

367
00:19:04.447 --> 00:19:07.342
All right, Vonne thanks so much for

368
00:19:07.342 --> 00:19:08.950
showing us how to work with Excel and

369
00:19:08.950 --> 00:19:12.100
the conditional formatting
abilities that it has inside of it.

370
00:19:12.100 --> 00:19:15.236
Very cool stuff, so get out there,
play around with it, understand it,

371
00:19:15.236 --> 00:19:17.478
assimilate it so
that you can use it on a daily basis.

372
00:19:17.478 --> 00:19:20.978
That being said it looks like we're out of
time for this episode, we do thank you so

373
00:19:20.978 --> 00:19:22.400
much for watching though.

374
00:19:22.400 --> 00:19:25.140
Signing off for Office Pro TV I've
been your host Daniel Lowrie.

375
00:19:25.140 --> 00:19:25.738
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

376
00:19:25.738 --> 00:19:26.926
>> And we'll see you next time.

377
00:19:26.926 --> 00:19:31.868

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore using outline and subtotals in Excel 2016. Here you will learn how to work with outlines to create collapsible groups of rows and columns to show/hide your data as well as add calculated subtotals to properly sorted ranges.
episodes.title: Outline and Subtotals

Notice that we now have totals and
averages on both sales, the average and

420
00:21:17.260 --> 00:21:22.350
total on the sales, the totals on
the calls and then we get our grand total.

421
00:21:22.350 --> 00:21:29.830
So you can do multiple subtotals and
multiple functions on your information.

422
00:21:29.830 --> 00:21:32.970
You just have to do it twice,
you just make sure you uncheck that and

423
00:21:32.970 --> 00:21:33.610
then take it off.

424
00:21:33.610 --> 00:21:35.460
So again, super handy,

425
00:21:36.480 --> 00:21:40.750
it's one of those kinda logical as long as
you kinda think of it in logical steps.

426
00:21:40.750 --> 00:21:43.610
Sort it, go ahead and
put all subtotals on.

427
00:21:43.610 --> 00:21:46.590
And then there you go, you can kinda
play around with this, and it's really,

428
00:21:46.590 --> 00:21:47.270
really handy.

429
00:21:47.270 --> 00:21:51.600
Now what if I went ahead and said,
I don't want these subtotals anymore?

430
00:21:51.600 --> 00:21:53.780
Anywhere within that range of information,

431
00:21:53.780 --> 00:21:58.560
go back to Subtotals, there is a Remove
All, just go ahead and take this off.

432
00:21:58.560 --> 00:22:00.080
Take it off, and then there you go,

433
00:22:00.080 --> 00:22:04.020
you're back to your data,
so love those functions.

434
00:22:04.020 --> 00:22:07.470
Organizing it with our groups and
doing our outlines so you can collapse and

435
00:22:07.470 --> 00:22:10.890
expand with buttons rather than
trying to find the unhides and

436
00:22:10.890 --> 00:22:13.040
you can't understand
what's going on in there.

437
00:22:13.040 --> 00:22:14.460
So, different ways, again,

438
00:22:14.460 --> 00:22:18.658
to analyze your data and be able to
find what you want out of those numbers.

439
00:22:18.658 --> 00:22:20.130
>> Very cool, Vonne, and like I said,

440
00:22:20.130 --> 00:22:23.630
I think this is a great thing that
we're going to continue to build upon

441
00:22:23.630 --> 00:22:26.500
as we move through Excel, so
great knowledge for you too.

442
00:22:26.500 --> 00:22:28.540
Play around with, mess around with and

443
00:22:28.540 --> 00:22:33.400
give yourself a little more
power as an Excel user, right?

444
00:22:33.400 --> 00:22:35.680
Cuz its very, very handy to have around.

445
00:22:35.680 --> 00:22:38.570
Vonne, thanks for
showing up how we can do that very thing,

446
00:22:38.570 --> 00:22:40.960
we do thank our good audience
out there for watching.

447
00:22:40.960 --> 00:22:41.550
But guess what?

448
00:22:41.550 --> 00:22:43.670
It's that time again for us to sign off.

449
00:22:43.670 --> 00:22:45.890
For Office PRO TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

450
00:22:45.890 --> 00:22:50.447
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.
>> And we'll see you next time.

451
00:22:50.447 --> 00:22:58.520
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne examine working with data formatted as tables in Excel 2016. Here they will cover table formatting options, adding/deleting table rows/columns, adding a total row, removing duplicates, and converting to a range.
episodes.title: Tables
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:06.530
[SOUND]
All right,

2
00:00:06.530 --> 00:00:10.318
greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of Office Pro TV.

3
00:00:10.318 --> 00:00:11.436
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:11.436 --> 00:00:14.968
And in today's episode, well,
I hope you're as excited as I am,

5
00:00:14.968 --> 00:00:18.700
cuz we're moving on with more in
our Excel 2016 Advanced series.

6
00:00:18.700 --> 00:00:20.060
It's gonna be a lot of fun.

7
00:00:20.060 --> 00:00:23.400
Joining us in the studio today to
lend her expertise on that topic for

8
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.270
us, our good friend, Miss Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:27.120
Vonne, how's it going today?

10
00:00:27.120 --> 00:00:30.425
>> I'm super excited,
as always when I'm on these episodes!

11
00:00:30.425 --> 00:00:33.406
[LAUGH] But today we're gonna talk
about one of my favorite things,

12
00:00:33.406 --> 00:00:34.212
which is tables.

13
00:00:34.212 --> 00:00:34.931
>> Tables.

14
00:00:34.931 --> 00:00:37.955
>> Tables, yes, in Excel.

15
00:00:37.955 --> 00:00:38.990
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

16
00:00:38.990 --> 00:00:39.935
>> No.
>> That didn't work.

17
00:00:39.935 --> 00:00:40.514
>> No it didn't.
[LAUGH]

18
00:00:40.514 --> 00:00:41.180
>> Just shut it down.

19
00:00:41.180 --> 00:00:44.666
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, but yes, we are gonna be talking

20
00:00:44.666 --> 00:00:48.325
about tables, and how to format
our Excel worksheets into tables.

21
00:00:48.325 --> 00:00:50.945
And so, well, first of all,
well, what is a table?

22
00:00:50.945 --> 00:00:52.343
Now when we talk about-
>> You put food on it, right?

23
00:00:52.343 --> 00:00:53.184
>> [LAUGH]
>> And then,

24
00:00:53.184 --> 00:00:54.304
everybody sits down-
>> Yeah!

25
00:00:54.304 --> 00:00:55.555
>> And breaks bread, it's amazing.

26
00:00:55.555 --> 00:00:57.305
>> Yeah, exactly!

27
00:00:57.305 --> 00:01:01.520
Well, in that same analogy, we all come
to the table in an organized fashion.

28
00:01:01.520 --> 00:01:04.767
And so we're all sitting around
a table and we're one unit, right?

29
00:01:04.767 --> 00:01:05.390
>> Correct.

30
00:01:05.390 --> 00:01:07.580
>> Well,
it's kind of the same thing in Excel.

31
00:01:07.580 --> 00:01:09.056
>> The analogy holds true then,
let's move on.

32
00:01:09.056 --> 00:01:11.828
[LAUGH]
>> Good job, totally ad libbed too.

33
00:01:11.828 --> 00:01:13.450
>> Yeah, it was.

34
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:15.680
>> But that's exactly what
we're going to be doing.

35
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:20.890
When we talk about tables in Word or
PowerPoint, then that's where it's like

36
00:01:20.890 --> 00:01:25.130
okay, well we're gonna make columns and
rows, and where they intersect is a cell.

37
00:01:25.130 --> 00:01:30.490
That's because, well PowerPoint and Word,
they're like blank pieces of paper.

38
00:01:30.490 --> 00:01:32.780
It's like, well Excel is a spreadsheet.

39
00:01:32.780 --> 00:01:36.540
It's already in columns and
rows, so how is that a table?

40
00:01:36.540 --> 00:01:40.674
Well in Excel, what that means is that,
it's recognizing it as

41
00:01:40.674 --> 00:01:45.421
an independent unit of data that has
some special features, that you're

42
00:01:45.421 --> 00:01:50.347
able to add to your table to help with
the styles, and like the look and feel.

43
00:01:50.347 --> 00:01:55.383
And also some kind of cool things that you
can do with some very simple functions,

44
00:01:55.383 --> 00:01:58.440
or what are called sub
totals within our tables.

45
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:03.520
So I think the best way to demonstrate
our tables is to well, do it.

46
00:02:03.520 --> 00:02:08.320
So why don't we jump down
into our tables.xlsx file?

47
00:02:09.320 --> 00:02:12.040
And we've been seeing a lot
of the same information,

48
00:02:12.040 --> 00:02:14.950
because we work at
Christmas Cats Incorporated.

49
00:02:14.950 --> 00:02:19.181
>> It's a great company, you should
check out the Glassdoor on that.

50
00:02:19.181 --> 00:02:21.800
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so like cat toys abound,

51
00:02:21.800 --> 00:02:25.926
and there's always free catnip,
and treats and everything.

52
00:02:25.926 --> 00:02:27.740
>> [LAUGH] Man,
scratching posts on every door.

53
00:02:27.740 --> 00:02:28.396
It's an amazing place.

54
00:02:28.396 --> 00:02:28.921
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

55
00:02:28.921 --> 00:02:29.828
>> She gonna love it.

56
00:02:29.828 --> 00:02:32.470
>> There it is.

57
00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:33.424
And that CEO Fuego, man, he's a gem.

58
00:02:33.424 --> 00:02:34.053
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

59
00:02:34.053 --> 00:02:35.975
we have some information here,

60
00:02:35.975 --> 00:02:39.542
and this is everything we've
been doing with Excel so far.

61
00:02:39.542 --> 00:02:43.668
We go ahead and put our data into our
cells, and we have our row references and

62
00:02:43.668 --> 00:02:44.970
everything like that.

63
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:48.220
And so we've done some sorting and
some filtering, but

64
00:02:48.220 --> 00:02:52.540
what if I wanted to add
in a row into this?

65
00:02:52.540 --> 00:02:55.450
If I right-click here over on row four.

66
00:02:55.450 --> 00:02:56.560
And then go to insert.

67
00:02:56.560 --> 00:03:01.930
Then it inserts an entire row into this
worksheet, which then goes ahead and

68
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:06.140
puts that into, if you wanna say,
this group of information and

69
00:03:06.140 --> 00:03:12.730
this group of information, because
they're not seen as independent units.

70
00:03:12.730 --> 00:03:14.699
They're just data in one spreadsheet.

71
00:03:15.950 --> 00:03:17.260
So that's where we're gonna go ahead and

72
00:03:17.260 --> 00:03:20.430
introduce the whole idea of,
let's format this as a table.

73
00:03:20.430 --> 00:03:25.970
So I just did an undo right there,
to not have that row inserted.

74
00:03:25.970 --> 00:03:29.320
So how do I tell this
group of information,

75
00:03:29.320 --> 00:03:32.810
this contiguous range
of cells to be a table?

76
00:03:32.810 --> 00:03:35.550
You just click anywhere in the table,
all right?

77
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:37.920
And then you come up to the home tab,

78
00:03:37.920 --> 00:03:39.970
the little button that
says Conditional Format.

79
00:03:39.970 --> 00:03:42.390
That's not Conditional Format,
we're not doing Conditional Formatting,

80
00:03:42.390 --> 00:03:43.135
we're doing one more over.

81
00:03:43.135 --> 00:03:45.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let's move over to where it says

82
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:47.250
Format As Table.

83
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:52.210
Pretty self explanatory, convert a range
of cells to a table with its own style.

84
00:03:52.210 --> 00:03:54.200
If you click Hold or
just click and drop-down,

85
00:03:54.200 --> 00:03:59.360
it gives you this drop-down menu that
gives you all of these default styles.

86
00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:00.410
Now, what is a style?

87
00:04:00.410 --> 00:04:04.230
We've talked about this, that a style
is just a named group of formatting.

88
00:04:04.230 --> 00:04:08.010
So we have here, for example,
if I hover over these medium.

89
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:11.640
It says that its name is
white table medium four, and

90
00:04:11.640 --> 00:04:12.760
that's just the name of it.

91
00:04:12.760 --> 00:04:13.410
And that's fine.

92
00:04:13.410 --> 00:04:16.920
Why don't we go ahead and click any one
of them, just to at least get it started.

93
00:04:16.920 --> 00:04:21.560
So if I click, it says all right it
noticed that, because I was in that

94
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:26.450
contiguous range of cells,
it finds like where the data ends in here,

95
00:04:26.450 --> 00:04:31.290
and it says, hey I've seen that,
this is saying from G1 to J13, yes.

96
00:04:32.480 --> 00:04:35.890
It does recognize that my table
is going to have headers.

97
00:04:35.890 --> 00:04:38.220
Cuz we do have a header
row of information.

98
00:04:38.220 --> 00:04:39.160
Headers are always good.

99
00:04:39.160 --> 00:04:43.800
You always want to label the tops of
your columns as what is this data.

100
00:04:43.800 --> 00:04:46.820
We click, OK, and then there you go.

101
00:04:46.820 --> 00:04:49.450
We have formatted this as a table.

102
00:04:49.450 --> 00:04:52.600
I'm gonna just click off this like,
in it so you can see.

103
00:04:52.600 --> 00:04:56.430
A few things to notice when we do this,
you have a contextual tab,

104
00:04:56.430 --> 00:05:01.650
the contextual tab at the top says that
this is the design tab of the table tools.

105
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:05.240
And we will go through a lot of these
options, as we go through this episode.

106
00:05:05.240 --> 00:05:08.970
But right now, I just wanted you to
notice that I have a contextual tab.

107
00:05:10.090 --> 00:05:13.650
Wonderful, notice the other thing
that happens is we have our filters.

108
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:18.190
We've talked about these little filter
buttons in our sort and filter episode.

109
00:05:18.190 --> 00:05:19.980
So that automatically gets added.

110
00:05:19.980 --> 00:05:25.580
And it's the same options that we had
in our filters with the same sorts,

111
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:29.530
and what do I want to see and
not see in this particular table?

112
00:05:31.020 --> 00:05:37.620
This is saying that this is one area
that is independent then another area.

113
00:05:37.620 --> 00:05:39.760
I am going to scootch over,
for just a second so

114
00:05:39.760 --> 00:05:41.150
you can see this a little better.

115
00:05:41.150 --> 00:05:41.980
The other thing to notice,

116
00:05:41.980 --> 00:05:46.010
when you formatted something as a table,
like how can I know that this is a table.

117
00:05:46.010 --> 00:05:49.770
If you look down at the bottom
right of the, kind of,

118
00:05:49.770 --> 00:05:53.070
end of this table,
you see this little guy right here,

119
00:05:53.070 --> 00:05:58.090
just looks like a little, I don't even
know what to call that, a backwards L?

120
00:05:58.090 --> 00:05:59.535
We'll call it that.

121
00:05:59.535 --> 00:06:05.800
[LAUGH] So that just indicates that that
is the end of the range of this table.

122
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:09.620
Now this will change, when you have your
mouse over it, to a two pointed arrow,

123
00:06:09.620 --> 00:06:16.200
to where you can change the boundaries
of what is defining this table.

124
00:06:16.200 --> 00:06:22.076
To exclude or include more information
that might be around that.

125
00:06:22.076 --> 00:06:25.090
So I'll zoom back out of there.

126
00:06:25.090 --> 00:06:26.300
Let's go ahead and do this.

127
00:06:26.300 --> 00:06:30.360
Let's come over here to this
other range of information, and

128
00:06:30.360 --> 00:06:31.950
let's format this is a table.

129
00:06:31.950 --> 00:06:34.720
So we can start really
seeing like the true

130
00:06:34.720 --> 00:06:37.990
nature of these two independent pieces.

131
00:06:37.990 --> 00:06:41.770
So anywhere within your range of cells,
you come up to format as table, and

132
00:06:41.770 --> 00:06:46.090
we'll just pick, doesn't matter which one,
I'm just gonna pick this one for now.

133
00:06:46.090 --> 00:06:51.343
Click OK, and then it goes ahead and
formats it, and I love,

134
00:06:51.343 --> 00:06:56.500
to me, the thing that I love
right away are the banded rows.

135
00:06:56.500 --> 00:06:58.280
Where it goes ahead and changes,

136
00:06:58.280 --> 00:07:01.910
it alternates between fills,
to where you can see it [INAUDIBLE].

137
00:07:01.910 --> 00:07:02.777
I dunno have you've ever done this,

138
00:07:02.777 --> 00:07:06.110
Daniel, like if you have something
printed out or it's on your screen.

139
00:07:06.110 --> 00:07:09.140
Have you ever had to like
take a piece of paper, and

140
00:07:09.140 --> 00:07:13.920
actually put it up into
the actual row to see across.

141
00:07:13.920 --> 00:07:14.440
>> Yeah, yeah.

142
00:07:14.440 --> 00:07:17.240
We're using like a mask or a blinder.

143
00:07:17.240 --> 00:07:20.220
So I don't see anything
I don't want to see.

144
00:07:20.220 --> 00:07:22.980
I can focus in what it is
I'm really looking for.

145
00:07:22.980 --> 00:07:24.840
>> Yeah,
I've actually taken a piece of paper and

146
00:07:24.840 --> 00:07:27.170
put it up on my monitor like this.

147
00:07:27.170 --> 00:07:28.620
Cuz I can't actually see.

148
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:31.641
Cuz my eye travels across and
it goes down one.

149
00:07:31.641 --> 00:07:35.078
When you have these
alternating bands here,

150
00:07:35.078 --> 00:07:38.067
I know Jack Bow tie keep in that orange.

151
00:07:38.067 --> 00:07:42.410
If I go down in the white, well,
that's the next record down there.

152
00:07:42.410 --> 00:07:46.228
And to be able to do this like without
a table, you'd just sit there and

153
00:07:46.228 --> 00:07:49.160
select every other row and
just change the fill.

154
00:07:49.160 --> 00:07:50.018
>> That sounds fun.

155
00:07:50.018 --> 00:07:50.856
[LAUGH]
>> No, it's not.

156
00:07:50.856 --> 00:07:52.485
[LAUGH] It's not at all.

157
00:07:52.485 --> 00:07:55.873
So you want to go ahead and
if you format as a table,

158
00:07:55.873 --> 00:08:01.146
you can quickly add that particular style,
which is pretty fun right there.

159
00:08:01.146 --> 00:08:06.415
Now, since there are two independent
units Wanted to show you what happens.

160
00:08:06.415 --> 00:08:10.945
If I try to do the same thing I did
earlier, where if I'm on Row 4, and

161
00:08:10.945 --> 00:08:16.831
I right-click on that, and I say, look, it
doesn't even give me the option to insert.

162
00:08:16.831 --> 00:08:18.580
It's like, hm, why?

163
00:08:18.580 --> 00:08:21.950
Okay, well there's something
that's it's not gonna let me do,

164
00:08:21.950 --> 00:08:23.430
because it's saying that.

165
00:08:23.430 --> 00:08:27.007
And even if you do get an insert, and
it tries to tell you to go ahead and

166
00:08:27.007 --> 00:08:30.977
put this in it will actually give me
a warning that says no, I can't do this.

167
00:08:30.977 --> 00:08:34.280
It's because you're going
to mess up the rows.

168
00:08:34.280 --> 00:08:35.400
And actually here, let me show you this.

169
00:08:35.400 --> 00:08:37.670
I think it's, there, watch this.

170
00:08:37.670 --> 00:08:40.167
If I say, all right let's insert,
well, it did it anyways.

171
00:08:40.167 --> 00:08:41.557
Okay, well, okay, you know what?

172
00:08:41.557 --> 00:08:44.080
Let's pretend it never happened,
let's roll back.

173
00:08:44.080 --> 00:08:48.370
It should go ahead and give you warning
that was like this is going to move

174
00:08:48.370 --> 00:08:50.730
some of the data within your tables.

175
00:08:50.730 --> 00:08:52.291
And it's gonna shift everything around.

176
00:08:52.291 --> 00:08:55.320
So let's go ahead and
format that back as a table.

177
00:08:55.320 --> 00:08:56.300
We'll just pick whatever one.

178
00:08:56.300 --> 00:08:57.520
We'll click OK.

179
00:08:58.610 --> 00:09:01.530
And so I cannot add individual rows.

180
00:09:01.530 --> 00:09:06.140
So then how am I supposed to start
working within these tables?

181
00:09:06.140 --> 00:09:09.750
You have to go back to the way
that you have to do it in Word and

182
00:09:09.750 --> 00:09:12.705
PowerPoint, is you start
right clicking on everything.

183
00:09:12.705 --> 00:09:15.630
Cuz notice up here in this contextual tab,

184
00:09:15.630 --> 00:09:19.248
it's not gonna have things like
insert a row or insert a column.

185
00:09:19.248 --> 00:09:23.740
Cuz if I wanted to put another row
in between let's say, Fuego and

186
00:09:23.740 --> 00:09:27.410
Simba right here because that's where
I want to put something, above it or

187
00:09:27.410 --> 00:09:30.010
below it, you have to think, where am I?

188
00:09:30.010 --> 00:09:31.840
So right now I'm in the Fuego cell.

189
00:09:31.840 --> 00:09:34.990
If I right click, that's where
you're going to get the insert.

190
00:09:34.990 --> 00:09:39.855
And notice that the insert here is
talking about Table Column to the Left or

191
00:09:39.855 --> 00:09:41.490
Table Row Above.

192
00:09:41.490 --> 00:09:44.570
The Delete, do you want to delete
the column or delete the row.

193
00:09:44.570 --> 00:09:48.090

You don't have to pre-think

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach cover the last item in the What-If Analysis tool group - goal seek. Goal seek is used when you know the desired result of your formulas, but want to experiment with cell values to achieve that result.
episodes.title: Goal Seek

So, I don't know if any of

episodes.description: Vonne and Zach discuss how to remove duplicate data in three different ways:  using the remove duplicate command, conditional formatting, and advanced filters.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to add a graphical element to your Excel 2016 spreadsheets. Here they will demonstrate inserting graphics from a file or online, as well as resizing, rotating, aligning, moving, and cropping your images.
episodes.title: Image: Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne dive deeper into working with graphics inside of Excel 2016. Here they will show you how to manipulate images by adding borders, effects, change picture styles, reset pictures, perform image corrections, add artistic effects, and add alternate text titles and descriptions for accessibility.
episodes.title: Images: Format

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne look at inserting and formatting shapes in Excel 2016. They demonstrate how to manipulate shapes by resizing, rotating, filling with gradients/colors, connecting shapes with lines, adding text, and editing their points.
episodes.title: Shapes: Add and Format

00:03:02.091 --> 00:03:04.412

00:03:04.412 --> 00:03:07.661

00:03:07.661 --> 00:03:13.730

00:03:13.730 --> 00:03:15.680

00:03:15.680 --> 00:03:21.332

00:03:21.332 --> 00:03:27.460

00:03:27.460 --> 00:03:31.240

502
00:24:42.000 --> 00:24:46.227
And so these Bezier handles, I sometimes
call them seesaws, you can pull the seesaw

503
00:24:46.227 --> 00:24:47.006
>> Can you do that again?

504
00:24:47.006 --> 00:24:47.870
>> Yeah.

505
00:24:47.870 --> 00:24:48.750
>> Can you do the little shimmy?

506
00:24:48.750 --> 00:24:51.643
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

507
00:24:51.643 --> 00:24:52.880
>> I'm like what did I do?

508
00:24:52.880 --> 00:24:55.511
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I'm demonstrating

509
00:24:55.511 --> 00:24:57.062
that the Bezier seesaw.

510
00:24:57.062 --> 00:25:00.552
>> That's right.
>> So I can take this and notice that it's

511
00:25:00.552 --> 00:25:05.900
curving how the path comes into
this point and then how it leaves.

512
00:25:05.900 --> 00:25:10.380
And so you can start making some really
interesting types of shapes going on

513
00:25:10.380 --> 00:25:13.910
here by grabbing those handles and
being able to change it.

514
00:25:13.910 --> 00:25:18.560
Like I said, not going to far into it but
just hey, grab it, pull it around and

515
00:25:18.560 --> 00:25:23.100
see what happens and you're like okay,
well this is my exploding comb?

516
00:25:23.100 --> 00:25:26.118
[LAUGH] We'll go with that.

517
00:25:26.118 --> 00:25:31.208
All right, now, where I was going first,
I got really distracted by the lightning,

518
00:25:31.208 --> 00:25:34.388
as I really wanted to talk
about the lightning, but,

519
00:25:34.388 --> 00:25:36.410
the fun little yellow dots, hm.

520
00:25:36.410 --> 00:25:42.540
Come over into our Insert
> Illustrations > Shapes.

521
00:25:42.540 --> 00:25:44.144
Let's start with a smiley face.

522
00:25:44.144 --> 00:25:46.690
Click, hold and drag and here's my smiley.

523
00:25:46.690 --> 00:25:50.730
And there's this yellow dot
that's in the middle right there,

524
00:25:50.730 --> 00:25:53.650
and you see it right there, okay?

525
00:25:53.650 --> 00:25:57.290
What that does is it will take it and
I can make it a frown.

526
00:25:57.290 --> 00:26:02.410
So what it does is it actually
modifies the shape of everything.

527
00:26:02.410 --> 00:26:08.713
So let's go over to another one,
we will do the starburst.

528
00:26:08.713 --> 00:26:10.210
Yeah, we'll take this one.

529
00:26:10.210 --> 00:26:15.225
Click, hold, and drag, and
notice if I take this yellow dot and

530
00:26:15.225 --> 00:26:20.315
move it in, see now it's actually
making the rays of the star thinner.

531
00:26:20.315 --> 00:26:20.945
>> Yeah.

532
00:26:20.945 --> 00:26:22.190
>> And more pointy.

533
00:26:22.190 --> 00:26:26.968
[LAUGH] And if I take it out, the it's
gonna go ahead and make it not so defined.

534
00:26:26.968 --> 00:26:28.400
You see what it's doing.

535
00:26:28.400 --> 00:26:29.725
>> It's after Thanksgiving dinner.

536
00:26:29.725 --> 00:26:32.356
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Right like here we go.

537
00:26:32.356 --> 00:26:36.240
So some of your shapes have yellow dots.

538
00:26:36.240 --> 00:26:40.490
I got distracted and I remembered nope,
lightning doesn't have the yellow dot.

539
00:26:40.490 --> 00:26:43.147
>> And now it's more like
a Salvador Dali painting [LAUGH]

540
00:26:43.147 --> 00:26:44.128
>> Exactly, yeah so,

541
00:26:44.128 --> 00:26:45.751
some of your shapes will have it.

542
00:26:45.751 --> 00:26:51.589
Another one that you can see the yellow
dots a lot is this particular shape,

543
00:26:51.589 --> 00:26:53.172
our rounded arrow.

544
00:26:53.172 --> 00:26:57.320
See, there's all sorts of yellow dots
in here, to where it will take and

545
00:26:57.320 --> 00:26:59.006
make like the hump-
>> Like rounding?

546
00:26:59.006 --> 00:27:01.115
>> Yes, you can take that and
make it either-

547
00:27:01.115 --> 00:27:02.006
>> More angular?

548
00:27:02.006 --> 00:27:05.552
>> Yes, that, [LAUGH] I'm glad,
you're doing really good.

549
00:27:05.552 --> 00:27:07.791
>> We do great at Password,
I think [LAUGH]

550
00:27:07.791 --> 00:27:10.369
>> [LAUGH] Right, what am I trying to say,

551
00:27:10.369 --> 00:27:12.720
Daniel will say it for me.

552
00:27:12.720 --> 00:27:17.130
And you can change the arrow,
how big the arrowhead is and

553
00:27:17.130 --> 00:27:20.900
how wide this goes and
all that kind of fun stuff.

554
00:27:20.900 --> 00:27:24.380
So if you see yellow dots,
just start grabbing and moving around and

555
00:27:24.380 --> 00:27:27.120
then you can see how
your shapes will change.

556
00:27:27.120 --> 00:27:29.540
So those can be a lot of fun.

557
00:27:29.540 --> 00:27:34.030
And one last thing cuz I wanted to kind
of come back to it with a gradient.

558
00:27:34.030 --> 00:27:39.030
If I came into the Fill and
chose that Gradient here, when you go

559
00:27:40.090 --> 00:27:45.240
down here, at the presets, behind my head,
you can see that the direction.

560
00:27:45.240 --> 00:27:47.740
This is where you can get
into your linear directions.

561
00:27:47.740 --> 00:27:50.175
And the one that's kinda fun
is if you choose the path.

562
00:27:50.175 --> 00:27:55.375
See how the gradient's gonna actually
follow the shape or the path right there.

563
00:27:55.375 --> 00:28:00.130
And so my gradient is actually going
to be in the shape of the star,

564
00:28:00.130 --> 00:28:04.650
rather than just the circular or
the linear or the radial.

565
00:28:04.650 --> 00:28:07.650
So that one's a lot of fun
that I wanted to show you,

566
00:28:07.650 --> 00:28:12.813
cuz that's just a really pretty
rainbowy star, like unicorns.

567
00:28:12.813 --> 00:28:14.210
>> [LAUGH]
>> You had to have the stars, and

568
00:28:14.210 --> 00:28:16.630
the rainbows all around, so there we go.

569
00:28:16.630 --> 00:28:20.020
And I believe that is all that I wanted
to cover in this particular episode.

570
00:28:20.020 --> 00:28:23.310
We'll have another one where we're going
to be talking about multiple shapes and

571
00:28:23.310 --> 00:28:25.550
how we can group them and align them.

572
00:28:25.550 --> 00:28:27.516
And I think we're gonna make a cat.

573
00:28:27.516 --> 00:28:30.350
>> How did we not see that coming, right?

574
00:28:30.350 --> 00:28:33.830
Well, Vonne, it has been tons
of fun to create shapes and

575
00:28:33.830 --> 00:28:36.170
add them into our Excel worksheets.

576
00:28:36.170 --> 00:28:37.830
It's been a lot of good times here.

577
00:28:37.830 --> 00:28:40.660
I look forward to seeing what else
we can do with them as we move

578
00:28:40.660 --> 00:28:41.670
forward in our series.

579
00:28:41.670 --> 00:28:43.240
But guess what?

580
00:28:43.240 --> 00:28:44.580
We've run out of time for this episode.

581
00:28:44.580 --> 00:28:46.910
We do thank you good folks out there for
watching.

582
00:28:46.910 --> 00:28:49.860
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

583
00:28:49.860 --> 00:28:50.760
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

584
00:28:50.760 --> 00:28:52.755
>> We'll see ya next time.

585
00:28:52.755 --> 00:28:57.631
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne continue working with shapes in Excel 2016, this time working with multiple shapes as well as icons. Here you will see how to select multiple shapes, duplicate, rotate, align, change stacking order, group/ungroup, and use the selection pane.
episodes.title: Shapes: Multiple Shapes and Icons
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.069
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.445 --> 00:00:08.043
All right, greetings everyone and

3
00:00:08.043 --> 00:00:10.661
welcome back to another great
episode of OfficePro.TV.

4
00:00:10.661 --> 00:00:13.767
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

5
00:00:13.767 --> 00:00:17.160
if you were here for more Excel,
then you've come to the right place,

6
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:19.997
cuz that's our series today,
Excel 2016 Advanced.

7
00:00:19.997 --> 00:00:23.740
You guys already know a little bit about
it, so we want to increase that knowledge.

8
00:00:23.740 --> 00:00:26.686
Here to help us do that very
feat is our good friend, Ms.

9
00:00:26.686 --> 00:00:29.834
Vonne Smith, Vonne, we're so
glad to have you yet again.

10
00:00:29.834 --> 00:00:32.257
Always a pleasure in the studio to
be with you, how is it going today?

11
00:00:32.257 --> 00:00:34.593
>> Why, thank you,
it's wonderful to be here.

12
00:00:34.593 --> 00:00:37.620
We're going to continue
on talking about shapes.

13
00:00:37.620 --> 00:00:41.362
So we had our first episode,
we were adding and formatting them.

14
00:00:41.362 --> 00:00:45.470
So this isn't a part two, cuz I try to
name them a little bit differently,

15
00:00:45.470 --> 00:00:49.317
cuz this is specifically working
with multiple shapes and icons, so

16
00:00:49.317 --> 00:00:51.792
we're gonna draw a little cat, all right?

17
00:00:51.792 --> 00:00:55.022
We're gonna make a little kitty cat, or
if you think about it, what's a cat?

18
00:00:55.022 --> 00:00:58.414
It's a circle, ears like-
>> Yeah, a couple of triangles and

19
00:00:58.414 --> 00:01:00.010
maybe another little circle.

20
00:01:00.010 --> 00:01:01.679
>> Yeah, put a little nose, right?

21
00:01:01.679 --> 00:01:05.256
Maybe a little mouth that
kinda goes like this.

22
00:01:05.256 --> 00:01:07.890
>> Yeah, little half-circles,
make some circles and cut them in half.

23
00:01:07.890 --> 00:01:08.867
>> Yeah, and
then we're gonna group them all together.

24
00:01:08.867 --> 00:01:09.880
>> This sounds fun.

25
00:01:09.880 --> 00:01:11.624
>> I know.
>> We're going to draw with Excel.

26
00:01:11.624 --> 00:01:14.099
>> I know, [LAUGH], here we go, right?

27
00:01:14.099 --> 00:01:15.313
[LAUGH]
>> It's like,

28
00:01:15.313 --> 00:01:17.478
I think the concept of why we're
using Excel is lost on me.

29
00:01:17.478 --> 00:01:19.268
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We're just going

30
00:01:19.268 --> 00:01:20.653
to add graphical elements so.

31
00:01:20.653 --> 00:01:22.599
>> Don't have Illustrator?

32
00:01:22.599 --> 00:01:23.373
Who needs that?

33
00:01:23.373 --> 00:01:24.508
>> Yeah!
You have Excel!

34
00:01:24.508 --> 00:01:25.363
>> You have Office Suite, right?

35
00:01:25.363 --> 00:01:27.632
>> Yes, they go hand in hand, [LAUGH].

36
00:01:27.632 --> 00:01:30.921
>> And you forget the fact that you
have things like Word, and [LAUGH].

37
00:01:30.921 --> 00:01:31.813
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

38
00:01:31.813 --> 00:01:35.584
>> Probably something more suitable too,
but it's in there, they put it in there.

39
00:01:35.584 --> 00:01:36.670
>> Exactly.
>> If you need to know how to do it,

40
00:01:36.670 --> 00:01:37.370
that's why we're doing it today.

41
00:01:37.370 --> 00:01:40.560
>> And we're exploring all the tools and
all the capabilities,

42
00:01:40.560 --> 00:01:44.433
because there are people out there that
will build an invitation in Excel.

43
00:01:44.433 --> 00:01:48.052
I think I might make a maybe a little
bonus episode of where we're gonna

44
00:01:48.052 --> 00:01:51.853
actually create, I have an invitation,
I just haven't actually gotten

45
00:01:51.853 --> 00:01:55.430
onto that worksheet tab,
into this workbook that I have right here.

46
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:57.630
So why don't we just go ahead and
hop on down in here?

47
00:01:57.630 --> 00:02:00.763
Because we've been working on
this insert images worksheet and

48
00:02:00.763 --> 00:02:02.927
just putting in the shapes and everything.

49
00:02:02.927 --> 00:02:05.741
We've put in the pictures of Fuegle and
Bishop,

50
00:02:05.741 --> 00:02:10.482
and we did all of our effects and strokes,
I keep saying strokes, my goodness!

51
00:02:10.482 --> 00:02:14.337
It's an outline, [LAUGH], so
we have all those different things.

52
00:02:14.337 --> 00:02:17.365
So we'll come over here since
there is an invitation.

53
00:02:17.365 --> 00:02:19.461
>> There is one right there.

54
00:02:19.461 --> 00:02:22.251
[LAUGH]
>> There is, but for now we're going to go

55
00:02:22.251 --> 00:02:25.844
ahead and concentrate, this is something
else that we'll be getting to,

56
00:02:25.844 --> 00:02:27.510
on working with multiple shapes.

57
00:02:27.510 --> 00:02:33.347
So how do I create, say, a duplicate
of my shapes, how do I rotate them?

58
00:02:33.347 --> 00:02:37.036
We did a little rotation of the other one,
but then we're going to flip them, and

59
00:02:37.036 --> 00:02:39.746
then we're going to align them,
and then keep on going, so

60
00:02:39.746 --> 00:02:41.668
why don't we draw our cat's ears first?

61
00:02:41.668 --> 00:02:45.179
So we'll come into our Insert
Illustrations and Shapes, and Danny,

62
00:02:45.179 --> 00:02:48.525
you had said, well, we should do
a triangle for the ears, right?

63
00:02:48.525 --> 00:02:52.242
So we'll go with our basic triangle
right here, our isosceles triangle,

64
00:02:52.242 --> 00:02:55.724
and it doesn't matter, cuz we're
gonna drag whichever way we want.

65
00:02:55.724 --> 00:02:58.931
So I'll click, hold, and
drag, and then we'll make it,

66
00:02:58.931 --> 00:03:01.314
yeah, about like that, that sounds good.

67
00:03:01.314 --> 00:03:04.913
But I can always come in here and
maybe make it a little wider and so on and

68
00:03:04.913 --> 00:03:05.464
so forth.

69
00:03:05.464 --> 00:03:10.679
So that looks like a nice little ear
right there, I need to rotate this, okay?

70
00:03:10.679 --> 00:03:14.994
So we're gonna kinda turn it around
like that, so you can kind of already

71
00:03:14.994 --> 00:03:19.115
think about that this is going to be
the left ear, or at least my left.

72
00:03:19.115 --> 00:03:23.743
So now I need another one, now,
copy and paste, totally fine,

73
00:03:23.743 --> 00:03:28.461
nothing wrong with a little Ctrl+C,
Ctrl+V, that's great,

74
00:03:28.461 --> 00:03:32.525
because I do want it to be
the exact same size of this ear.

75
00:03:32.525 --> 00:03:37.641
So you could do that, or you could
do a little trick that while moving,

76
00:03:37.641 --> 00:03:39.910
if you hold your Ctrl key.

77
00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:44.338
We've actually done this on a couple
other examples when we were, excuse me,

78
00:03:44.338 --> 00:03:45.557
duplicating cells.

79
00:03:45.557 --> 00:03:48.866
We had it selected and then we did the
move tool and then we hold the Ctrl key

80
00:03:48.866 --> 00:03:52.566
and then we went ahead and duplicated our
cell, so same thing with your objects.

81
00:03:52.566 --> 00:03:54.009
Hold that Ctrl key, and

82
00:03:54.009 --> 00:03:58.711
you can actually see your arrow turns into
a white arrow with a plus sign on it.

83
00:03:58.711 --> 00:04:03.100
Click, hold, drag across, let go of the
mouse first before you let go of the Ctrl,

84
00:04:03.100 --> 00:04:05.190
and now I have an ear, okay, perfect.

85
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:10.599
Now, I really want this to be rotated
the same degree but the other side,

86
00:04:10.599 --> 00:04:14.871
so I could grab here and turn it,
but I want it to be exact.

87
00:04:14.871 --> 00:04:19.421
So there is something up on our format
contextual tab over here on rotate where

88
00:04:19.421 --> 00:04:20.829
it is flip horizontal.

89
00:04:20.829 --> 00:04:23.404
So I basically just wanna turn it over and

90
00:04:23.404 --> 00:04:26.297
that would be the exact
same ear duplicated.

91
00:04:26.297 --> 00:04:27.970
>> On the other side.

92
00:04:27.970 --> 00:04:30.745
>> Yeah, so we're going to horizontally
flip this and then move that over,

93
00:04:30.745 --> 00:04:31.432
okay, perfect.

94
00:04:31.432 --> 00:04:37.295
Now, I want to have these ears be equal,
aligned up at their tops,

95
00:04:37.295 --> 00:04:41.613
so we're going to go
through our align options.

96
00:04:41.613 --> 00:04:45.620
But before we go with our align options,
you're gonna need to be able to select

97
00:04:45.620 --> 00:04:49.037
both the things that you want to
have aligned, so how do we do that?

98
00:04:49.037 --> 00:04:53.330
You hold your Shift key, if you hold your
Shift key, you can select multiple items.

99
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:55.842
And if I had four or
five things that I needed to align across,

100
00:04:55.842 --> 00:04:58.517
then you just keep that Shift key down,
click, click, click.

101
00:04:58.517 --> 00:05:01.711
Make sure you get the boxes around
each one of them, and then let go of

102
00:05:01.711 --> 00:05:05.378
your mouse, and let go of the Shift key,
and now what do I want to do with this?

103
00:05:05.378 --> 00:05:10.245
And this could be for, not just aligning,
maybe I want both of these to be filled

104
00:05:10.245 --> 00:05:13.659
in with yellow or orange,
so it's not just alignment,

105
00:05:13.659 --> 00:05:18.693
it's just I want this thing to be applied
to multiple things, where are we going?

106
00:05:18.693 --> 00:05:23.211
We're going over here to Align, so
in this way we want to go with Align Top.

107
00:05:23.211 --> 00:05:27.567
Notice that you can see on the icons here,
if you're doing tops, middle, bottoms,

108
00:05:27.567 --> 00:05:31.742
that's with things going across, if you
have things going this way then you would

109
00:05:31.742 --> 00:05:35.341
go left, center, or right, so
just kind of watch in those pictures.

110
00:05:35.341 --> 00:05:40.397
I will zoom back out, click on the aligned
tops, and so now I know that those

111
00:05:40.397 --> 00:05:45.152
are exactly at the top point,
they're together, they are aligned.

112
00:05:45.152 --> 00:05:48.727
I should probably not say together,
cuz that kind of lends us up to grouping,

113
00:05:48.727 --> 00:05:51.820
we are not there yet, all right,
where are we going to go now?

114
00:05:51.820 --> 00:05:55.050
Well, we need to make the cat face, so,

115
00:05:55.050 --> 00:06:00.658
we're going to come back over into Insert,
and we will draw a circle.

116
00:06:00.658 --> 00:06:04.410
Grab my circle, click, hold, and
drag, it doesn't have to be exact,

117
00:06:04.410 --> 00:06:07.620
because we can always come back
in once I've drawn the shape.

118
00:06:07.620 --> 00:06:11.700
And then make this a little wider,
make this a little wider,

119
00:06:11.700 --> 00:06:13.620
and that looks pretty good.

120
00:06:13.620 --> 00:06:14.146
>> That does look pretty good.

121
00:06:14.146 --> 00:06:16.246
[LAUGH] It's already very cat like.

122
00:06:16.246 --> 00:06:19.236
>> Yeah, it's like I've drawn
a couple of these before.

123
00:06:19.236 --> 00:06:22.473
[LAUGH]
>> Vonne just sits at her desk drawing

124
00:06:22.473 --> 00:06:24.931
cats all day, are you working, Vonne?

125
00:06:24.931 --> 00:06:25.757
Yeah, totally working.

126
00:06:25.757 --> 00:06:28.604
[LAUGH]
>> I do sometimes wonder about that,

127
00:06:28.604 --> 00:06:32.665
there's people walking by and I am
creating fun things and rainbows, and.

128
00:06:32.665 --> 00:06:34.677
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, it is for the episode,

129
00:06:34.677 --> 00:06:35.714
I promise, [LAUGH].

130
00:06:35.714 --> 00:06:39.510
All right, so that looks about good,
okay, stop fidgeting, stop, there you go,

131
00:06:39.510 --> 00:06:40.215
that's good.

132
00:06:40.215 --> 00:06:45.823
[LAUGH] So now I have the face of my cat,
we need some eyes, right?

133
00:06:45.823 --> 00:06:50.162
So why don't we come into here and we'll
go with another circle, we'll just click,

134
00:06:50.162 --> 00:06:51.079
hold, and drag.

135
00:06:51.079 --> 00:06:56.803
Now I'm going off to the side here, so
I can kinda move this over into it, and

136

So we come over here, four pointed arrows,

Well, that's not really what I wanna do,

00:20:51.764 --> 00:20:52.869

And you can go through, and

00:21:44.107 --> 00:21:48.304
Because there will be certain times where
maybe you don't want it to act like

cuz there's some kind of fun things in

I wanna take, now,

00:22:07.287 --> 00:22:11.090

471
00:22:15.159 --> 00:22:19.577
So if you took this and

00:22:19.577 --> 00:22:23.814

474
00:22:28.797 --> 00:22:32.853
Now notice, when you convert it to shapes,

00:22:32.853 --> 00:22:37.533

476
00:22:37.533 --> 00:22:42.221

477
00:22:42.221 --> 00:22:45.794
So sometimes using that Smart Art

478
00:22:45.794 --> 00:22:48.623

479
00:22:48.623 --> 00:22:52.874
There is another thing that we're going

00:22:52.874 --> 00:22:55.993

481
00:22:55.993 --> 00:23:00.593
And when you go into actually doing

00:23:00.593 --> 00:23:04.808

483
00:23:04.808 --> 00:23:08.070
I can't remember if Smart Art is one
of those, but it's one of those,

484
00:23:08.070 --> 00:23:09.782
if I didn't want it to act like that,

485
00:23:09.782 --> 00:23:13.070
making it shapes might make it a little
bit easier for certain things.

486
00:23:13.070 --> 00:23:16.135
So I know things like tables,
remember doing format as tables?

487
00:23:16.135 --> 00:23:20.180
You can't do that in a shared workbook, so
you'd have to convert it to a range, so

488
00:23:20.180 --> 00:23:21.954
at least you know that this exists.

489
00:23:21.954 --> 00:23:25.350
Stop acting like a Smart Art graphic and
just be plain old shapes, so

490
00:23:25.350 --> 00:23:28.756
that's what that button can do for
you, and you might need to do it.

491
00:23:28.756 --> 00:23:33.249
So that, I believe, covers all the cool
things that Smart Art graphics can do for

492
00:23:33.249 --> 00:23:34.915
us, it's art that is smart.

493
00:23:34.915 --> 00:23:36.416
>> [LAUGH] It is very, very smart art.

494
00:23:36.416 --> 00:23:40.043
I love the way that it just starts
resizing and removing itself so

495
00:23:40.043 --> 00:23:44.218
that it adjusts to what input you're
giving it, very, very cool stuff.

496
00:23:44.218 --> 00:23:48.398
And like we've mentioned a couple of
times, it's doing all the hard stuff so

497
00:23:48.398 --> 00:23:51.867
that when you want to make an overall
change to what's going on,

498
00:23:51.867 --> 00:23:55.852
you don't have to start moving things and
redraw this and undo that,

499
00:23:55.852 --> 00:23:59.291
it's too much work for us,
Smart Art takes care of that for us.

500
00:23:59.291 --> 00:24:00.878
Vonne, a really cool way for

501
00:24:00.878 --> 00:24:05.510
us to add another graphical element to our
Excel spreadsheets or our worksheets and

502
00:24:05.510 --> 00:24:09.632
workbooks and all the other cool
terminology used inside of Excel [LAUGH].

503
00:24:09.632 --> 00:24:10.683
>> [LAUGH]
>> We do thank you for

504
00:24:10.683 --> 00:24:13.227

looking at the clock over there,

505
00:24:13.227 --> 00:24:16.398
it looks like we're out of time for
this episode, we hope you guys enjoyed it.

506
00:24:16.398 --> 00:24:19.608
Signing off for OfficePro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

507
00:24:19.608 --> 00:24:20.399
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

508
00:24:20.399 --> 00:24:22.497
>> We'll see you next time.

509
00:24:22.497 --> 00:24:27.281

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne culminate our graphical element skills in Excel 2016 by creating a birthday invitation. Here you will see how to use page layouts, orientation, formatting text, moving cells, inserting images, grouping images, etc. Then they show you how to create a two-sided invitation, printing, marking paper for orientation, and adjusting element placement for printer adjustment.
episodes.title: Create an Invitation

WEBVTT

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne will explore shared workbooks in Excel 2016. Here they cover the why and how of sharing workbooks as well as showing you what to expect when working with shared workbooks. They also look at sharing through OneDrive for online collaboration.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne dive into track changes in Excel 2016. Here they will explain why you would want to enable tracking and how to accomplish that. They also take you through the tracking experience to help you understand how this may benefit you in your working environment.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore implementing data validation inside of Excel 2016. Here they will show you how to prevent erroneous data types from being entered by restricting the type of data that a user can insert. They also show you how to create custom error messages, highlight invalid data, and protect worksheets with a password.
episodes.title: Data Validation

So let's open up that data

It gave me a warning, and

But as opposed to this one, when I typed

So, that was the one that I was

So, I wanted to look at this and

So, I do know that this is pulling

remember that hidden worksheet.

So, let's do that first.

I wanna unhide.

00:27:39.090 --> 00:27:44.206
I can see what the problem is, right

00:27:50.540 --> 00:27:54.560
We said we wanna go from this particular

We talk a lot about absolute references

00:28:32.410 --> 00:28:35.360

00:28:49.000 --> 00:28:53.920

00:28:53.920 --> 00:29:00.250
In mine over here, notice if I go over to

00:29:00.250 --> 00:29:01.340

00:29:01.340 --> 00:29:02.990
And this is why it didn't work.

00:29:02.990 --> 00:29:06.420
You go over here and now it says A6.

00:29:06.420 --> 00:29:10.990
I moved down one, so it moved

00:29:10.990 --> 00:29:13.510

563
00:29:13.510 --> 00:29:18.870
And if you go down one more,

564
00:29:18.870 --> 00:29:19.685
>> You're a great counter [LAUGH].

565
00:29:19.685 --> 00:29:21.350
>> Wow, thanks [LAUGH].

566
00:29:21.350 --> 00:29:23.270
I've worked really hard.

00:29:23.270 --> 00:29:27.050
So, that's the problem

00:29:28.710 --> 00:29:31.159
We are going to say, no matter what,

00:29:35.666 --> 00:29:38.680
So, let's come into here, we're gonna go.

572

00:29:46.410 --> 00:29:48.080

575
00:29:48.080 --> 00:29:51.900
Let me show you what I mean, and

00:29:51.900 --> 00:29:54.923
If you put your cursor here,

00:29:54.923 --> 00:29:59.213

It's actually moving around

00:30:08.325 --> 00:30:11.272

So let's not do that.

584

So I need to make sure

The other single quote,

And now we're gonna do dollar sign,

590
00:30:35.600 --> 00:30:40.440
So now it's saying don't ever change

591
00:30:40.440 --> 00:30:41.770

00:30:41.770 --> 00:30:47.667
You click OK, you zoom back out,

00:30:54.563 --> 00:30:57.467
1- 1 -1, there you go.

595
00:30:57.467 --> 00:30:59.415
And if we go down, sorry.

596
00:30:59.415 --> 00:31:03.045
[LAUGH] No, I'm not gonna continue,

597

And then if I go down to here, 1-1-1, it's

599
00:31:13.130 --> 00:31:16.160
That is why it didn't work,

600
00:31:16.160 --> 00:31:18.560
I think now I can sleep better.

601
00:31:18.560 --> 00:31:19.700

602

because if you're like me, I'm like, well,

00:31:23.588 --> 00:31:24.581

604

>> [LAUGH]
>> Well then show me how to fix it.

605
00:31:26.480 --> 00:31:31.550
So now that I've come full circle,
our department of redundancy department.

606
00:31:31.550 --> 00:31:34.230
[LAUGH] Come back around to keep on going,

607
00:31:34.230 --> 00:31:37.710
to make sure you know how to do data
validation with cell references.

608
00:31:37.710 --> 00:31:38.564
>> All right, Vonne.

609

Well thank you so much, because that's

It's not gonna work, as we saw.

So you gotta go in there and make sure

613
00:31:49.260 --> 00:31:52.840
Lot of fun stuff, and we've learned

[LAUGH]
>> That is true [LAUGH].

00:31:53.760 --> 00:31:55.710
>> A little bit, just a little bit,

00:31:55.710 --> 00:31:56.460
Right, ladies and gentlemen?

617
00:31:56.460 --> 00:31:57.620
It's been a lot of fun today.

618

Vonne, we do thank you for joining us.

619

We do thank our audience for

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne dive into workbook security in Excel 2016. Here they will show you security features like protecting workbooks and worksheets, restrict to editing  certain ranges, mark as final, encrypt file with password, restricting access, and digital signatures.
episodes.title: Workbook Security

Of protecting a worksheet,

So we did talk a little bit about

I have a workbook called
Workbook Security.

00:01:16.147 --> 00:01:17.000
Yeah, I know.

30

I'm so clever with these names, aren't I?

31
00:01:18.768 --> 00:01:19.761
>> Man you're like.

32

You should write album names or something.

33
00:01:21.688 --> 00:01:23.501
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yes, super creative.

34
00:01:23.501 --> 00:01:25.915
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] They're just yep, there you go.

35
00:01:25.915 --> 00:01:28.120
[LAUGH] So we have our file here.

36

Cuz in the data validation episode,
we were doing different ways to

37
00:01:34.050 --> 00:01:40.190
limit what type of information people are
putting into ourselves and our worksheets.

38
00:01:40.190 --> 00:01:45.786
So if I want it to be a whole number or we
had that drop down, that was really fun.

39
00:01:45.786 --> 00:01:51.484
And then we also talked about, well in
this sense if I'm gonna start securing

a worksheet and lock my cells down.

41
00:01:56.755 --> 00:02:01.436
Now in our cells, actually,
all of your cells are locked by default.

42
00:02:01.436 --> 00:02:03.660
What do you mean they're
locked by default?

43
00:02:03.660 --> 00:02:04.500
I can click on them.

44
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:06.390
I can come over here and select this.

45
00:02:06.390 --> 00:02:08.870
And I can change this Christmas Cats and
I can do all this stuff.

46
00:02:08.870 --> 00:02:10.930
So I don't know what you mean.

47
00:02:10.930 --> 00:02:13.167
Well, they're locked by default.

48
00:02:13.167 --> 00:02:18.630
And it will be enforced when
you protect the worksheet.

49
00:02:18.630 --> 00:02:20.270
Well if you don't ever
protect the worksheet,

50
00:02:20.270 --> 00:02:24.380
then you're never gonna have that
enforcement of the locked cells.

51
00:02:24.380 --> 00:02:26.470
So, let me show you what I mean.

52
00:02:26.470 --> 00:02:28.640
In our Format Cells dialogue box.

53
00:02:28.640 --> 00:02:31.170
Now we've been to this
a couple different times.

54
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:35.573
We've gone to it from our dialogue box
launcher button within our different

55
00:02:35.573 --> 00:02:36.135
groups.

56
00:02:36.135 --> 00:02:37.990
And I'm gonna show you by right-clicking.

57
00:02:37.990 --> 00:02:41.646
So you could right-click on any cell and
go to Formal Cells and

58
00:02:41.646 --> 00:02:43.421
it takes you right into this.

59
00:02:43.421 --> 00:02:46.885
We talked a lot about number formats and
custom number formats.

60
00:02:46.885 --> 00:02:50.197
And we went through these different tabs
with the alignment, and the font, and

61
00:02:50.197 --> 00:02:51.340
the border, and the fill.

62
00:02:51.340 --> 00:02:54.277
But we didn't really come over
here to the protection tab.

63
00:02:54.277 --> 00:02:55.370
And that's where it is.

64
00:02:55.370 --> 00:02:56.330
Right there, look at that.

65
00:02:56.330 --> 00:03:01.363
It says locked, locking cells
are hiding formulas that way when you,

66
00:03:01.363 --> 00:03:05.132
until you [SOUND] let me try that again,
okay rewind.

67
00:03:05.132 --> 00:03:05.955
>> You can read.

68
00:03:05.955 --> 00:03:07.870
[LAUGH]
>> Well, we'll try.

69
00:03:07.870 --> 00:03:12.670
[LAUGH] Locking cells or
hiding formulas has no effect

70
00:03:12.670 --> 00:03:15.590
until you protect the worksheet.

71
00:03:15.590 --> 00:03:19.865
>> It's an interesting thing that they
did it that way that it's by default it's

72
00:03:19.865 --> 00:03:20.706
turned on, but

73
00:03:20.706 --> 00:03:25.134
it only actually does what it's defaulted
to do is if you turn something else on.

74
00:03:25.134 --> 00:03:26.013
>> Yes.

75
00:03:26.013 --> 00:03:27.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, it's kinda weird and

76
00:03:27.180 --> 00:03:29.235
like why would you wanna
have the default be locked?

77
00:03:29.235 --> 00:03:31.209
[CROSSTALK]
>> I'm guessing people were forgetting

78
00:03:31.209 --> 00:03:32.248
>> [LAUGH]

79
00:03:32.248 --> 00:03:33.340
>> They were like, yeah,

80
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:36.680
let's do this whole protect sheet thing
and why is it not protecting the sheet?

81
00:03:36.680 --> 00:03:38.090
I've got to turn that on.

82
00:03:38.090 --> 00:03:39.140
So they put it on by default.

83
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:43.170
And now when people go to actually
protect the sheet, it is already enabled.

84
00:03:43.170 --> 00:03:44.432
>> Yeah.
>> That would be my guess.

85
00:03:44.432 --> 00:03:48.543
>> Yeah, and if you also think about
how many cells we have, in a worksheet.

86
00:03:48.543 --> 00:03:49.320
>> There's a lot.

87
00:03:49.320 --> 00:03:52.500
>> Yeah, and you wouldn't want
to select just a little bit and

88
00:03:52.500 --> 00:03:54.925
say let's lock these, and
all the other ones are unlocked.

89
00:03:54.925 --> 00:03:57.617
And that means they could go and
select all that stuff.

90
00:03:57.617 --> 00:04:02.292
So I think it's easier, if it's let's
go ahead and choose the ones that you

91
00:04:02.292 --> 00:04:06.822
don't want to be locked, rather than
where we have over a million rows and

92
00:04:06.822 --> 00:04:09.910
65,536 columns, that's a lot to select.

93
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:13.921
So I think that's another reason of why
they've kind of thrown it in that reverse.

94

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne demonstrate how you can customize the Excel 2016 interface to make it more efficient for your workflow. Here you will see how to customize the Ribbon, make custom keyboard shortcuts, and other options in Excel that can be manipulated for ease of use.
